Found 3000 Baskets Of Sherds

Some 3000 baskets of fragments of pottery (sherds), out of
which were collected fine charac·
teristic sherds from the Earlv
Bronze age, were recovered b~
the group, it was said.
The earliest trace of human occupation was found on the hill in
one of the many crevices in the
bed-rock, where a few sherds be··
longing to the Early Bronze age,
before the 19th century B. C.,
were discovered.
The site, unoccupied during
most of the Late Bronze Age, is
believed to have been rebuilt by
the Israelites in the late thirteenth century, said Dr. Albright.

"With preliminary work and several weeks of preparing the plans
and getting the material ready for
division, the campaign lasted for
about three months," Dr. Albright
said. "We dug for nearly fifty
working days, with an average
force of I IO laborers, all from the
local clan of Halhul to which the
hill belongs. Our relations with the
natives were excellent; their shi"ekh,
'Abd el-Qader Yusi£, helped us
very materially, and proved himself a most satisfactory man to deal
with.
"We cleared nearly 8ooo square
meters of the summit to bed-rock,
and filled almost the entire area
again before the end of the campaign. The denudation of the ruiTis
is partly due to the fact that the
town was repeatedly abandonned
after being destroyed, and partly
Glue to the fact that the builders of
the Byzantine and Arabic Beth-Zur
employed the more ancient site as
a convenient quarry. The entire
southeastern part of the city wall
was thus removed and at least half
of the Hellenistic houses in the too
stratum, including the entire fortress complex, ·were raised to below
floor level.
"We found an almost incredible
mixture of sherds of all ages, except where house walls and floor.
levels are well-preserved. Happily
we found respectable areas of wellpreserved stratification belonging to
every single age."

The Goucher College Debating
Society, represented by Miss Thelma Tharp and Miss Harriet Salinger, will meet the representatives
of Princeton University in Catherine Hooper Hall, 25th and St. Paul
Streets, today, at 8 :oo P. M.
The subject of the debate is "Resolved, That the United States
degelates to the Geneva Conference
in February, 1932, initiate measures
leading to a fifty per cent universal budgetary disarmament. An
admission fee of 35c will be
charged.

Election By Points

"Election is based on a rigid point
system, and every effort is made to
guard against the danger of petty
politics or personal prejudice," Mr.
Cotton said.
"vYith the newly elected members
of the Circle, I wish to leave one
word of caution: For the next year,
at least, the reputation and welfare
of our Society is in your hands. Do
riot shirk the responsibility that
goes with the honor. Properly
used membership in 0. D . K. gives
you an opportunity to increase ten
fold the value of your service to
your Alma Mater. See that you
make the most of this opportunity."

University, Mr. Cotton served as

one of the four founders of this

PHARMACIST TO

TODAY AT 4P.M.
Dr. Edward Kremers, of Wisconsin University, To Speak
In Dohme Lecture Series

PLANTPIGMENTATION
HYPOTHESIS IS TOPIC
Lecturer Is One Of Country's
Foremost Chemists: Educated At Wisconsin
Today Dr. Edward Kremers,
director of the Pharmaceutical
Experimental Station of the
University of Wisconsin, will
speak at 4 P. M. in Remsen Hall.
His subject will be "Quinhydrons
Hypothesis of Plant Pigmentation."
Dr. Kremers, one of the foremost chemists in the country,
was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, in 1865. He received the
Ph. G. degree from the University of Wisconsin in 1886 and his
B. S. in 1888 from the same university. He studied abroad and
in 1890 the degree of doctor of
philosophy was conferred upon
him by Gottingen. Since he has
received a Phar. M. from the
Philadelphia College of Pharmacy, and quite recently, in 1921,
an honorary Sc. D. was given him
by the University of Michigan.
At University Of Wisconsin
His academic career has been
spent entirely at the University
of Wisconsin, where he has been
successively instructor in Pharmacy and professor of Pharmaceutical Chemistry. In addition,
since 1913, he has directed the
Pharmaceutical
Experimental
Station at the university.
For many years he was editor
of the Pharmaceutical Review
and at present is co-editor of the
Standard National Dispensatory.
During the period 1900-10, he was
chairman of the Committee on
Volatile Oils of the United States
Pharmaceutical ·Revision Committee. Dr. Kremers is also the
member of a number of learned
societies, including scientific organizations in France and Germany.
Author Of Text Book On Oils
· He is the American author of
Gildemeister - Hoffmann~ Kremers' Volatile Oils, a standard textbook ·on the subject.
Dr. Kremers will be the second
speaker on the lectureship this
year. Dr. Leo H. Baekeland of
Columbia was the first,

PHARMACIST TO
LECTURE HERE
TODAY AT 4P.M.
Dr. Edward Kremers, of Wisconsin University, To Speak
In Dohme Lecture Series

PLANTPIGMENTATION
HYPOTHESIS IS TOPIC
Lecturer Is One Of Country's
Foremost Chemists: Educated At Wisconsin
Today Dr. Edward Kremers,
director of the Pharmaceutical
Experimental Station of the
University of Wisconsin, will
speak at 4 P. M. in Remsen Hall.
His subject will be "Quinhydrons
Hypothesis of Plant Pigmentation."
Dr. Kremers, one of the foremost chemists in the country,
was born in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, in 1865. He received the
Ph. G. degree from the University of Wisconsin in 1886 and his
B. S. in 1888 from the same university. He studied abroad and
in 1890 the degree of doctor of
philosophy was conferred upon
him by Gottingen. Since he has
received a Phar. M. from the
Philadelphia College of Pharmacy, and quite recently, in 1921,
an honorary Sc. D. was given him
by the University of Michigan.
At University Of Wisconsin
His academic career has been
spent entirely at the University
of Wisconsin, where he has been
successively instructor in Pharmacy and professor of Pharmaceutical Chemistry. In addition,
since 1913, he has directed the
Pharmaceutical
Experimental
Station at the university.
For many years he was editor
of the Pharmaceutical Review
and at present is co-editor of the
Standard National Dispensatory.
During the period 1900-10, he was
chairman of the Committee on
Volatile Oils of the United States
Pharmaceutical ·Revision Committee. Dr. Kremers is also the
member of a number of learned
societies, including scientific organizations in France and Germany.
Author Of Text Book On Oils
· He is the American author of
Gildemeister - Hoffmann~ Kremers' Volatile Oils, a standard textbook ·on the subject.

Next Monday
The organization meeting of
the Johns Hopkins University
German Club will be held next
Monday, November 23, at 8
o'clock in Levering HalJ, it was
announced today.
Plans for future meetings will
be discussed at this meeting
which marks the revival of activities of the German Club. Baron
u. E. von Gienanth, German Ex
change Student, will talk for half
an hour and then will lead a discussion in German.
It has been planned to hold
three meetings a month. At one
of these meetings a noted speaker will be asked to speak in English; at the other two, discussions
in German will be held. All people who can understand and speak
German are invited to attend.

SEASON'S PRACTICE

The first practice of the swimming team was held last W ednesday at the Knights of Columbus
Pool, Cathedral and Madison
Streets. Further practices, it
was stated by Coach Hambleton,
will be held at this pool twice a
week, on 'vVednesdays and Fridays, at 4 :30 P. M.

the leadership of the following
varsity men who will take charge
of their specialty:
Hanhart and Doeller........ 1500 yards
Boyce and Cook. ....... ,......... 440 yards
Sadler and Stern........ Breast stroke
Reid and McConnell ................ Divers
Besides these there will also be
the 200 yard relay, the 150 yard
back-stroke, and the 50 and 100
yard dashes.
Memberships Available
In order to facilitate improved
practice sessions membership in
the Knights of Columbus will be
available to the squad members.

met from the budget of the team.
